titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

lg.l: O God, to thee my heart is drawn
And to thy glory will I sing
I will awake at early dawn,
And praise on Harp and Lute my king.
Thee to the People will proclaim
Among the Nations thee will praise
Above the clouds extol thy name
Above the Heavens thy glory raise.
Be thou exalted, God supreme

l.hi: Loud to thy glory will I s

lg.l: High above Heaven—all Earth above.
Thy best beloved, O redeem
Save—save and answer—boundless love
God spoke, in holiness divine
His voice I hear, with joy and pride—
Oer Shechem will I stretch my line
And Succoth’s valley will divide.

div.p: Call at J. G. Chapman’s. Painter’s Committee on Manufactures did not meet— H. Horn there— H.R.U.S. Key still sick— Houston’s trial again postponed. Plummer’s Speech in defence of the Administration, and against the last. Suspended— Hubbard’s Revolutionary Pension Bill— Daniel’s Speech— Yeas and nays taken about ten times— Previous Question— Bill pass’d to 3d. reading 126 to 50. Talk with J. Davis. G. Blake— Adjourn’d at 5. George Harrison, an Englishman from Liverpool here— And afterwards Payton Gay late in the Evening. Dr Dyott met me twice— Very anxious about his glass.

lg.l: Mine Gilead, mine Manasseh know;
My Helmet, Ephraim shall be
From Judah’s lips my Law shall flow—
In Moab, my wash-bason see.
O’er Edom will I cast my shoe
My hand o’er Palestine shall sway.
Come—who shall search the City through
To Edom who shall lead the way?
O God, our armies wilt thou bless?
Wilt thou forsake us in disdain?
O grant us, aid in our distress
O God—all human help is vain.
Yes—in the Lord our God we trust
Our host with victory to crown—
To triumph he will load the just,
And trample our Oppressors down

div.p: Sat to J. G. Chapman; half an hour— Committee on Manufactures—all present—Dr Dyott with his glass phials and bottles— Read part of the Bill from the Secretary of the Treasury to alter the Tariff— Bundles of Documents. H.R.U.S. Key still sick. I moved the printing of 10000 copies of Tariff-bill and documents to be selected. Whittlesey notified me to attend Blue-book Committee to-morrow— Plummer finished his Speech—Slade—Revolutionary Pension Bill passed.
Harbour and river-Bill in Committee of the whole. Everett Chairman. Archer’s sally. T. H. Hall. Adjourn’d at six P.M.

lg.l: God of my praise, hold not thy peace
Against me Slanders foul arise.
My foes, to multitudes increase
And forge, for my destruction, lies.
With malice they beset my way.
Against me, without cause they fight
My love with enmity repay
And curses for my prayers requite.
My good, with evil they reward—
Against him raise thy righteous hand
O, let the wicked be his Lord
And at his side let Satan stand—
Against him let the Sentence go
Let prayer be sinful for his sake—
Few be his days, and fill’d with woe.
His Office, let another take.

div.p: Committee on Manufactures at 9. Findlay, Worthington, Horn, Barbour Dayan—Dr Condict absent. Read Alvin Bronson’s Letter— Committee on the Blue-book Whittlesey and J. W. Taylor. To meet again at call of the Chairman— H.R.U.S.— Mercer Resolution to ventilate the House. F. S. Key finished. Houston asked to address the House— Postponed till Monday. Bill for improvement of harbours and removing obstructions of rivers— In Committee of the whole J. W. Taylor Chairman— Reported to the House— Adjourned at 5. Mrs Adams dined at Mr Frye’s— Dr Dyott and his boys, Mr Frye, and J. Connell here this Evening.

lg.l: His orphan children, widow’d wife
Be want and beggary their doom
O let them seek their bread with strife
Let famine all their days consume
Let fierce extortion grasp their all
His labour let the stranger steal
Let him in vain for mercy call
No mercy let his orphans feel.
Waste thou his progeny away
Blot from the future age their name
His fathers wickedness display
Still brand his mother’s Sins with shame
Against him let thy wrath endure
Still let him writhe beneath thy frown.
He had no pity on the poor
He broke the broken hearted down.

div.p: Committee on manufactures at 9. Condict, Findlay, Barbour, Dayan and Horn there—Worthington absent. Began upon the Bill from the Secy of the Treasury— Incorrectly printed— His letters of Correction Dr Dyott, and his glass vials.

H.R.U.S—Adjournment over to Monday postponed till next week. Business of the District of Columbia— Alexandria Canal Bill—Doddridge—Mercer—Felder—Blair—Polk Everett Bill rejected— Bridge postponed— H. Clay, Dr Wainwright, N. Silsbee. H. L. White—Bank Documents—Adjourned. N. Sellers here this Evening— Card wire— Writing Counter Bank Report. Thunder Shower.

lg.l: Behold him—curses loud invoke—
O let them on himself recoil
He bound them round him like a cloak
O let them search his bones like oil.
Be this the girdle round his waist
Let this his only garb compose
Thy wrath, Jehovah let them taste
Dash out thy vengeance on my foes.
But O, to me, thy grace extend
Thy love, O Lord, my God impart—
Thou, of the wretched art the friend;
And I am desolate at heart.
Gone, as declining shadows sink
Swept, like the locust tribes away.
My tottering knees with fasting shrink—
My flesh is wasting with decay.

div.p: Committee on Manufactures. Dr Dyott there—Findlay absent— Discussed the Bill of the Secretary of the Treasury. Much disagreement of opinion. Meet again Monday Morning. H.R.U.S—Slade on the Wiscasset Collector’s case. Harbour and river Bill—Ocracoke inlet T. H. Hall—Arkansas river—Cumberland River—Letcher’s Speech. lost 63 to 80— Gave Stansberry my Manuscript to be copied.
Mrs Adams dined at her brothers— I visited this Evening Genl. Root who has a broken arm— Call at Mr T. B. Johnson’s— Mr and Mrs Frye and Mrs Smith there.

lg.l: Their Scorn, their fable I am made
Their heads, with Sneers at me they shake
O Lord Jehovah, grand me aid
O save me for thy Mercy’s sake.
That they, thy wonders may confess
And own thy Majesty divine
Be theirs to curse, and thine to bless
Let shame be theirs, and gladness mine
O let my foes be clothed with shame
Confusion’s Mantle oer them throw.
My voice shall praise Jehovah’s name
With praising Millions I will go.
For he beside the poor shall stand
He the oppressor shall controul
Shall raise, in righteousness his hand
And shield from wrong the humble Soul

div.p: At St. Johns Church— Mr Hawley read prayers for second Sunday after Easter— Dr Wainwright preached from Luke 16.31. In the afternoon he read prayers and preached from Philippians 3.10. That I may know him, and the power of his Resurrection—
Visit between the Services from General Jesup— Letter from J. S. Barbour

lg.l: “Sit at the right hand of thy God”—
Thus to my Lord, Jehovah spoke
From Zion, he shal will I send the rod
Till I thy foes thy footstool make
Thy willing people in the day
When thou thy forces shalt review
Thy worship’s beauties shall display
Fresh, as the womb of Morning’s dew
The Lord hath sworn, nor will repent—
Thou, for all ages art my priest—
As once Melchizedek was sent
Whose order since at Sinai ceas’d.
The Lord, incens’d, at thy right hand
Shall crush the proudest monarchs head
To judgment call the heathen Land
And fill the region round with dead.

div.p: Committee on Manufactures. Barbour absent— The rest all present.— Treasury Bill canvass’d— Dissentient opinions. Committee equally divided. H.R.U.S—Presented petition from Cohasset— Abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia laid on the table— Memorial from Manufacturers of Musical Instruments— Referred to Committee on Manufactures— H. Everett and E. Whittlesey Post Office Resolution R. M. J. Houston made his defence Harper’s motion to discharge him— Huntington’s Amendment to declare him guilty of breach of privilege— And Speech—adjourn’d— W. S. Smith W. F. D’Wolf and Sullivan Bowdoin here.

lg.l: Oer distant Lands his arm shall stretch
And smite, of multitudes the crown
And from unnumber’d fields shall fetch
The meed of glory and renown
From every stream let in the way,
For him refreshing tides shall flow
And all mankind shall own his sway
And Earth his matchless might shall know
Praise ye the Lord—the anthem raise
His praise— Assembled Saints, recite
His deeds, how great—how fit for praise
To all who in them take delight.
His wonders to the end of time
In righteous glory shall endure
Yet thron’d in Majesty sublime
He still is gracious to the poor.

div.p: Met M’Duffie and Watmough in the Committee Room of the Committee of Ways and Means— Minority Bank Report. Excus’d from Committee on Manufactures.— Condict, Findlay, Dayan and Worthington. Horn absent. M’Duffie’s report, not quite finished. H.R.U.S. Houston’s trial. Polk—Ellsworth—Drayton—Cook of Ohio. Postponement at the motion of Doddridge. Blunt called me out— Took a book for him from the Library. A. J. Cazenove from Alexandria. Grievances— Asks my aid for their Canal. N. Biddle’s answers to Cambreleng’s questions— Letter from Biddle. Rain.

lg.l: His wondrous works shall none forget,
Bounteous, compassionate and kind—
Nor ever fail’d his Mercy yet
To keep his Covenant in mind
His People have beheld his might
To them he gave the heathen’s Lands
His word is sure, his Laws are right—
And Truth and Justice arm his hands
Ay they shall stand forever fast—
From him to us redemption came
Forever shall his promise last
Holy and Reverend is his name
Lord— Wisdom in thy fear begins
Thy Saints shall walk therein secure.
His Mercy shall forgive their Sins—
His praise forever shall endure

div.p: Committee on Manufactures. Made progress in revising M’Lane’s Bill— All present except J. S. Barbour.

H.R.U.S— Houston’s trial— Doddridge’s Speech Conclusive. Beardsley’s half Speech. three hours— Questions to postpone and adjourn— No Quorum— Yeas and Nays 80 and 36— Wayne in the Chair for Speaker— In the Evening, Jos. Blunt, J. Connell, R. Letcher, Anderson Bullitt
Meriam with Letter from Presdt. Quincy— S. D. Daiken with Letter from E. Bacon—here this Evening.
Extracts from my Letter Book 1810. for Jos. Blunt and J. Connell.

lg.l: Praise ye the Lord—and blessed he
Who in his precepts takes delight
Renown’d on Earth his seed shall be
Blest are the children of the Upright.
Wealth—Riches—in his house shall dwell
He never shall desert his trust—
Light shall illuminate his cell
His heart is generous and just.
The good man, kindness shews, and lends—
His cause, Discretion shall sustain
His Memory, grateful praise attends
And to all ages shall remain
No evil tidings shall he dread
His heart shall in Jehovah trust
The Lord’s protection shields his head
And tramples all his foes in dust

div.p: Committee on Manufactures— All but J. S. Barbour present. Continued revisal of M’Lane’s Bill—adjourn’d till Tuesday at 9. O’Clock, Worthington going away— J. M. Mason of Alexandria. E. J. Lee— Their proposed Canal. In the Speaker’s room with Mason. H.R.U.S. Beardsley finished his Speech—Sutherland—T. R. Mitchell—Crane—Burgess ask’d postponement— Refus’d— Call of the House— Various propositions— Postponed till 10 to-morrow— Adjourned half past five— M’Duffie ready with his Report— I wrote upon mine while the house was in Session.

lg.l: He scatters blessings—feeds the poor
His name with glory shall be crown’d—
His praise forever shall endure
His truth the wicked shall confound
His might, the wicked shall behold
His hopes are destin’d to decay—
Ay he shall perish as of old—
Gnash with the Teeth, and melt away.
Praise ye the Lord— His name adore
O ye his Saints—extol his fame
From this time forth, forever more
Forever blessed is his name.
Long as the race of Time shall run
Above the Heaven’s his glory raise
The rising and the setting Sun
Shall speak alike Jehovah’s praise

div.p: H.R.U.S. at ten A.M. M’Duffie presented the minority Bank Report— I said I should present mine on Monday— I met M’Duffie and Watmough in the Clerk’s Office— Slight Modification of the Report which I then signed— Houston’s trial—Burgess, Archer—J. L. Kerr—Dickson—Questions. Call of the House—Huntington’s first Resolution (amendment) carried 106. 89. Speaker’s decision reversed— Resolution to exclude Houston from the privileged Seats lost 97. 84— Houston to be reprimanded by the Speaker. Adjourned 1/4 before 11. P.M— Session of 13 hours.

lg.l: Who with Jehovah can compare
The Lord our God, who dwells on high
Yet stoops to see the things that are
On Earth, in Ocean, in the Sky.
The poor he raises from the dust
The needy from the dunghill brings
With princes seats him high in trust—
Yea seats him with his People’s kings
He from the barren woman takes
The sorrows and reproach away—
A joyful mother of her makes,
And causes her at home to stay—
Sing praises to Jehovah’s name
His praise let all mankind record.
His praise let Earth and skies proclaim
Ye unborn ages, praise the Lord.

div.p: Left my unfinished Bank-Report at M’Duffie’s lodgings— Call at Judge Cranch’s— He was at Court at the Capitol— Tables taken away from H.R.U.S.— Matting for the Carpet— At Chapman the painter’s room— He was gone to Baltimore— Call at the Treasury twice— Conversation with Mr M’Lane about his Tariff Bill— Met and conversed with J. Davis— Jos. Blunt here—H. Seymour and his Son. E. and Mrs Everett. Dr. and Miss Bartlett here. Blunt dined with us— Asked a call for the Instructions to H. Wheaton and Correspondence concerning the Danish Treaty— My Bank report manuscript lingers.

lg.l: When Israel out of Egypt went—
Forth from a race of strange descent
And language, not their own.
The hallow’d Ark, in Judah’s hand
For Israel’s tribes, Canaan’s land
Became Jehovah’s throne
Ocean beheld the deed and fled
Jordan turn’d backward to his head
The mountains skip’d like rams.
Why, backward fleddest thou O Sea?
O Jordan, wherefore didst thou flee?
Why skip’d the hills like lambs?
Earth, tremble at Jehovah’s nod—
Quake, at the presence of thy God
The God of Jacob’s flock
Who turn’d the mountain to a Lake
And caus’d to gush, for Israel’s sake
A fountain from the Rock.

div.p: At 2d. Presbyterian Church. Communion day. A stranger preach’d from Solomon’s Song 6.10—Christ and the Church— Another administered the Communion. 2. Misses Inches Mrs. Lee, and Mr Davis (son of Jonathan Davis[)] there— Afternoon two other preachers with Mr Smith— One preached from Luke 12.47–48—

Mrs Adams spent the Eve at her brother and at Mrs Frye’s. I was engaged with John till past midnight in making out a list of the documents to accompany my Bank Report. Sent the remainder of my Manuscript to be copied, and received 9. Columns of proof.

lg.l: Not unto us, O Lord—we pray
Not unto us, be glory given
Why should the scornful heathen say
Where now is he—the Lord in Heaven—
In glory be thy name enroll’d
Creation bows to thy commands
Their idols—Silver are—and gold
Their Gods—the work of human hands.
Yes, they have mouths, but they are dumb
And eyes they have, but they are blind.
Sound, to their ears can never come
Their noses cannot snuff the wind
Their hands—their feet are made in vain—
Their throats no utterance supply
Their makers, like themselves remain—
Like them, all, on them who rely.

div.p: Judge W. Cranch here, and took the acknowledgment of my Deed to G. Johnson of lot 18 Square 231. Jos. Gales with part of Bank Report manuscript. Mr Roberts manufacturer of white Lead— H.R.U.S.—Archer presents Houston’s protest. Houston reprimanded by the Speaker— Elutheros Cook of Ohio, presents an insulting Letter from E. S. Davis. Motion to refer it to a select Committee lost 87 to 85. Stanberry’s Motion for enquiry into the fraud—Select Committee ordered—T. H. Arnold’s speech— He shot at by Heard— I presented my Bank Committee Report. Offered Resolution calling for Danish Treaty Papers— Ask’d consideration one veto— Evening—Mrs Sullivan Jas. Bowdoin, and J. Connell here.

lg.l: O Israel trust thou in the Lord
He is thy helper and thy shield
O House of Aaron trust the Lord
He is your helper and your shield.
All ye, who fear him, trust the Lord
He is your helper and your shield
He will be mindful of his word
Abundant blessings, he shall yield.
The house of Israel, Aaron’s race,
And all who fear him, he will bless
The small, the great shall share his grace
His boundless goodness—all confess.
You and your children shall increase
Blest with the Lord Jehovah’s aid—
His hand shall prosper you in Peace
The Lord, who Heaven and Earth has made

div.p: Jonathan Hunt Member H.R.U.S. died at 6. this Morning— Committee on Manufactures all present. adjourned till after the adjournment of the house— H.R.U.S. H. Everett announced the death of Mr Hunt. House voted to attend his funeral to-morrow. Committee of arrangements ordered Message to the Senate— House adjourned till Thursday Morning— Committee on Manufactures met again— Went through the revision of the Bill from the Secretary of the Treasury. Adjourned to 4. P.M— J. Connell here this Evening.

lg.l: The Lord is Ruler of the Skies—
Earth to the Sons of man he gave
Praise to his name can never rise
From the dead Silence of the grave
But we, his goodness will confess
And we, his mercy will adore—
From this time forth his name will bless
And Praise the Lord, forever more
I love the Lord, because his ear
To me is graciously inclin’d
Because my voice he deigns to hear
Because a friend in him I find.
Death, and the Grave my heart appall’d
Subdued to Sorrow’s dire controul
Then, on Jehovah’s name I call’d.
O Lord—deliver thou my Soul.

div.p: My wife, with Mrs Nowlan—Mrs Pitts and Louisa, left us for Quincy— J. Kirk drives them, in the Carriage.

I called upon the Secretary of the Treasury— Conversation upon his Tariff-Bill— Committee on Manufactures—all present. We finished the revisal of the Tariff-Bill. Adjourned till 9 to-morrow Morning— I was employed in the Clerk’s office with Mr Perry directing him to make out a fair copy of our Bill— Letter to my Son Charles— at 4. P.M—the Corpse of Mr Hunt was brought into H.R.U.S— Short address and prayer by the Revd Mr Durbin. P.U.S. and Secretaries—V.P. and Senators attended. Genl. H. A. S. Dearborn went with me to the grave, at the Navy-Yard Cemetery— May-flies by Millions. How apt an emblem— Home near 7— Summer weather.

lg.l: The Lord is gracious—he is just
Yea—full of Mercy is our God
In him the humble put their trust.
He rais’d me from Oppression’s rod.
My Soul, return unto thy rest
Death’s shaft Jehovah hath repell’d
The tears of sorrow hath suppres’d
My feet, from fabling hath upheld.
Still do I breathe the breath of life,
And still Jehovah’s name will bless—
He sav’d me from the hand of strife
He was my comfort in distress.
My rashness how shall I record—
Mankind, all Liars I declar’d.
What shall I render to the Lord;
For all the Blessings I have shar’d—

div.p: Committee on Manufactures— The Bill fairly copied out. Read by Sections to the third Section—adjourned till to-morrow at 9. H.R.U.S—Dr Condict asks suspension of Rule to offer Resolutions on the outrages. rejected 83 to 94. Slade on the Wiscasset Collector—Apportionment Bill—Everett’s Speech—Polk’s reply— Opinions of Washington’s Cabinet—on the apportionment Bill of 1792— Previous question called by Bates of Maine—sustained— House disagree to the amendment of the Senate. 134 to 56. M’Duffie moves that his Tariff-bill be taken up next Monday— At my suggestion agrees to Wednesday— Mr Duponceau here this Evening.

lg.l: Salvation’s cup will I display
And call upon Jehovah now
Now, before all his people pay
The homage of my suppliant vow.
Dear to the Lord Jehovah’s sight
For Saints the thread of life is spun—
I am thy Servant—God of might—
Thy Servant, and thy handmaid’s Son
Thou hast releas’d me from my vow
Jehovah’s name will I display
And in thy People’s presence now
Thanksgiving’s sacrifice will pay
In midst, Jerusalem of thee
Here in his Courts my vows record—
Come to his holy Temple, ye—
Ye Sons of Israel—praise the Lord.

div.p: Committee on Manufactures. Mr Macauley attended with Specimens of Oil-Cloths. Made further progress in the Bill. H.R.U.S—Slade continued his Speech on the case of the Wiscasset Collector. My Resolution calling for the papers of the Danish indemnity Negotiation was adopted. Harbour and River Bill— Military or negotiable road in Maine— Bill passed to 3d reading 102, 74— Many members at the races. Mr Calhoun and Mr M’Duffie paid me an Evening visit— Also W and Mrs Lee.

lg.l: O praise the Lord, ye Nations—all
Before him, all ye people fall
His name, his praise record—
To us—his Mercies have no bound
With him—Eternal Truth is found
Ye Nations, praise the Lord
Thanks to the Lord Jehovah give—
Because his Mercy lasts forever
Let Israel’s children, while they live
Declare, his Mercy lasts forever.
Let Aaron’s house now sound his fame
Because his Mercy lasts forever.
Let all who fear him now proclaim
Jehovah’s Mercy lasts forever.
On him I call’d he lent his ear
He deign’d to answer and protect me.
The Lord is with me—wherefore fear
How can the wrath of man affect me?
The Lord will aid me—he is just
And I may bid my foes defiance
Tis better in the Lord to trust
Than place on human help, reliance

div.p: Committee on Manufactures— Mr Macauley and his floor-cloths there. Committee finished revisal of the Bill. My Report not ready—but to be read on Monday—wofully defective— Clayton, Cambreleng and Thomas publish in the Globe; the Resolution respecting Biddle— Harbour Bill passed— Senate recede from Amendment to the Apportionment Bill— Several Appropriation Bills passed in Committee of the whole— Speaker absent— C. C. Clay in the Chair Ellsworth Chairman of the Committee of the whole— Adjourned at 5. Saw H. G. Otis in the house.

lg.l: Tis better in the Lord to trust
Than place on princely men reliance
Nations would trample me in dust
The Lord shall set them at defiance.
They swarm like bees in thousands round
Jehovahs vengeance shall annoy them
Like crackling thorns they shall be found
The Lord Jehovah shall destroy them
With fierce assault thou didst me wrong
Before the Ruler of Creation
He is my glory and my Song
The Lord himself is my Salvation
The just Salvation shall enjoy
Jehovah’s hand shall not disdain me
My foes, his right hand shall destroy—
Jehovah’s right hand shall sustain me.—

div.p: A.M. Heard Mr Smith, from Jeremiah 6:14. and 8.11. the same text. Peace Peace, when there is no Peace— No service this afternoon, Sunday School Union at Dr Laurie’s— F. Hassler here— Still at work for the Treasury Department. Dr. Huntt Hip-bath— Second bath in the Evening. John wrote for me. Day past in severe pain—
21. V:15. Monday— Sleepless and painful Night

lg.l: I shall not die, but I shall live
The Lord hath granted my petition
The Lord chastis’d, but will forgive
Nor turn me over to perdition.
Open of righteousness the gates
And I to praise the Lord will enter
For here, as history relates
The vows of all the righteous centre.
Thee will I praise, as I have us’d
For thou hast sav’d me from the scorner
The Stone, the builders had refus’d
That Stone has now become the corner.
Thus the Lord’s doings are display’d
And not to worship him were madness
This is the day the Lord hath made
O, let it fill our Souls with gladness.

div.p: Committee on Manufactures. Worthington absent. J. S. Wright— Further discussion of the Bill. I was directed by the Committee to state to the House that the Bill would be reported on Wednesday. H.R.U.S—Slade continued his speech— Business of the District of Columbia. Five short Bills— Speaker called me to the Chair—as Chairman of the Committee of the whole House— The Bills pass’d through without debate— Bridge Bill rejected— House adjourned before 4. N. Biddle, in the house. Gales ask’d for my Tariff Report— Mr Frye here this Evening— I was in severe pain most of the day, and unable to write in the Evening.

lg.l: Save, I beseech thee, save us now
O Lord Jehovah send thy blessing
We from thy Temple spread the vow
And bless the man, thy name professing
God is the Lord, who shows us light
Bind fast the victim to the altar
Thy name O God, is my delight.
My voice to praise thee shall not falter
Lord, I will praise thee while I live
Nor cease to bless thy name—no—never.
Thanks to the Lord Jehovah give
Because his mercy’s last forever.
The Lord in my distress extreme
Heard the loud cry, my Sorrows wrung
From lying lips my Soul redeem
Redeem me from the fraudful tongue
Foul Slanderer who shall lay thee low?
How shall thy falsehood’s meet return?
Shafts from a mighty Prince’s bow
Like coals of Juniper they burn.

div.p: Awaked in the night with pain Severely suffering all this day— Committee on Manufactures—Worthington absent—read the fragments of my Report. Bill to be reported to-morrow. Sat till Noon. H.R.U.S. Bill for Indian annuities—discussed— Silk bill at last taken up. Drayton moves Mansfield in Connecticut—rejected. Polk moves to strike out enacting clause. rejected— Bill reported to the House. Adjourned— Saw N. Biddle and Jos. Gales. Wrote to conclude the Tariff-Report. John wrote for me also this Evening. Consulted with J Davis upon the provisions of the Bill.

lg.l: Alas for me! and is it so
That I in Mesech must reside?
And am I destin’d to the wo
In Kedar’s desart to reside
Too long my Soul has sought in vain
To flee, from Peace’s foes afar
For when my voice would Peace obtain
They answer with the Trump of War.
Up to the hills I lift mine eyes
Where should I turn mine eyes for aid?
Where but to him who made the skies,?
The Lord, who Heaven and Earth has made
Thy feet from stumbling he shall keep
His eyes thy Guardian shall not close
Thy guardian, Israel shall not sleep;
Nor slumber in supine repose.

div.p: Genl. H. A. S. Dearborn and J. S. Wright here—and Jos. Gales— Committee on Manufactures— Worthington absent. Instructed me to report—H.R.U.S. Report and Bill presented— M’Duffie’s Tariff-bill called up. Postponed till Monday. 91— 89. Finished the manuscript of my Report after it has been presented to the House— Bill and Report to be printed. 10.000 copies and referred to Committee of the whole House on the State of the Union— Silk Bill rejected. 98 to 71— Revised proof sheet of my Bank Report— Call at Office of National Intelligencer to patch up a flaw in the Tariff Report— Rain J. S. Wright—Manufacturer of Coarse Woollens, Evening here.

lg.l: The Lord himself shall be thy stay
He, on thy right hand is thy shade—
The Sun shall not scorch thee by day
Nor Moon at night, thy rest invade
The Lord, from thee, all ill shall charm—
His Mercy, cease not to adore—
His strength shall save thy Soul from harm
From this time forth, forever more.
Hark! to thy house, I hear them call
O Lord! the sound my heart elates
Come—visit we that hollow’d wall
Jerusalem—within thy gates
Built, is Jerusalem again
And thither Israel’s tribes repair—
Jehovah’s favours to obtain
And pay their vows of worship there

div.p: Call on L. M’Lane—Secretary of the Treasury— Conversation upon the Tariff-Bill & Report. To see him again to-morrow. Committee on Manufactures Short Meeting. H.R.U.S. Misunderstanding as to 35 or 50 per Cent on Woollens— Sent for the Bill, and Stopp’d the press— Indian annuity Bill—in Committee of the whole. Bell of Tennessee in the Chair— Revolutionary Pensioner’s Bill from the Senate passed to 3d. reading— Adjourned at 4— Assorted Bank Report Documents with M. S. C. Clarke. Dined with Mr Silsbee—Calhoun—Hayne, Tazewell. Chambers, Frelinghuysen Bell of New-Hampshire Waggaman, and L. Anderson of Kentucky there— Sprague came in— Fire in my chamber this Evening. Invitation from Genl. Macomb.

lg.l: There Seats of Judgment there have place
And Truth and Justice bear the sway
There are the Thrones of David’s race—
Peace for his holy City pray
Let all who love thee prosper still—
Peace, O Jerusalem be thine
O that Jehovah’s bounteous will
Within thy Palaces may shine
Companions, Neighbours, here we meet
And brethren in each other see
Thee, for their sakes, my Soul shall greet
And pray, Jerusalem for thee
Forever in thy Walls be Peace
For here Jehovah’s Temple stands
Thy grateful child, shall never cease
To God, for thee, to raise his hands.

div.p: P. R. Fendall here. Committee on Manufactures— The Bill to remain as printed. Genl. Findlay absent—assorted remainder of the documents for my Bank Report— Index to them made— Cambrelengs— Bank Mission Report and Instructions. He has them and declines giving them— Finally promised Coll. Watmough to give them.

H.R.U.S.—Alexandria Canal bill, pass’d Committee of the whole, and to third reading. Call of Massachusetts Delegation to meet, to-morrow morning— I called and gave notice to J. Davis and Choate. Dr. and Mrs Huntt were here this Evening— I could not write.

lg.l: O thou that dwellest in the skies
I call thy mercy to my aid—
His Master thus the Servant eyes—
Thus to her Mistress turns the maid—
Thy Mercy—Mercy we invoke
For thy support we cry aloud
We sink beneath the Scorner’s yoke
We perish, victims of the proud
But for the Lord upon our side—
Redeem’d, may Israël now exclaim
But for the Lord our faithful guide
When raging foes against us came
Then had they swallow’d us alive
Against us when their fury glow’d
Then had it been in vain to strive
Then had the whelming Torrent flow’d

div.p: Committee on Manufactures missed Meeting— Met only Dr Condict. The Massachusetts Delegation in the House met in the Committee Room of the Committee on the Militia— I asked of them to determine whether they would support the Bill as reported by the Committee on Manufactures. Stated the case and left them to deliberate. Mr Everett told me they had agreed to meet again to-morrow Evening. H.R.U.S. Slade finished his Speech on the Wiscasset case. Question taken— Referred to Secretary of the Treasury. Charles C. Johnston—decision that he is entitled to his Seat. Dined with J. S. Barbour. Calhoun. S. Smith. Troup. Tazewell W. R. King, Carson, Hawkins of N.C M’Intire. R. M. Saunders there. Carson’s invitation for next Saturday.

lg.l: Proud Waters had oerwhelm’d our heads
O God—our refuge is thy throne
His Snare in vain the fowler spreads
The bird escapes—the bird has flown—
Thus from the Snare our foes have set
Escape we with Jehovah’s aid—
Thy hand, Jehovah, breaks the net—
The hand which Earth and Heaven has made
They in the Lord who put their trust
Shall stand like Zion’s mountain fast
Firm and immovable, the just
Shall for unnumber’d ages last
As round Jerusalem the Hills,
Jehovah girds his People round—
Now, and forever more he wills
That Strength with Justice should be found

div.p: J. S. Wright here. Left a Letter with me. Going to-morrow. With Mary to the Capitol. Heard Harriet Livermore from Matthew 24.–29.30.31— Her Address. Saw no left arms with crape. Call at Louis M’Lane’s. Conversation with him upon our Tariff Bill— He thinks we retain the duties too high— Afternoon at St. John’s Church heard a Stranger read prayers for 5th. Sunday after Easter. Another preached from Jeremiah 8.22— W. Lee and Jonathan Davis here this Evening.

lg.l: No Sinful Sceptre shall have power
To turn the righteous Soul to wrong
Lord, on the good thy blessings shower
And make the heart of wisdom strong
But they who turn to winding ways
O bid them with the wicked cease—
And Israël’s voice his God shall praise
And Israel’s land be blest with Peace.
Lord, when to Zion we return’d
We thought it but a dream
Our Souls with exultation burn’d
Our gladness was extreme
Behold—exclaim’d the heathen race
How God protects them still
Great God—the wonders of thy grace
With bliss our bosoms fill

div.p: Attended at the chamber of the Committee on Manufactures. Doctor Condict only there H.R.U.S. Dr Condict moved to suspend the rule for his Resolutions concerning the outrages on members of the house—rejected— Thomas of Louisiana’s Resolution also— Tariff-Bills of the Committee of Ways and Means— M’Duffie spoke about three hours— House then adjourned. Watmough, and N. Biddle wished to withdraw the Documents of the Accounts of members of Congress with the Bank, to which I consented. T. L. M’Kenney here this Evening. Told me the Circumstance of the Indian Rations contract, much implicating J. H. Eaton and S. Houston.

lg.l: As rivers through the desart flow
Lord, let our tribes return
That they who now in tears must sow
To reap in joy may learn
Go weeping forth, and sow thy seed
To goodness yield the Spring
A smiling Summer shall succeed
And sheaves of gladness bring.
Except the House, Jehovah build
The builders toil in vain
Except the Lord the City shield
The watchman wakes in vain.
In vain, ere morning dawn ye rise
And nightly vigils keep
His bounty shall alone suffice
To give the same in Sleep—

div.p: Met E Whittlesey of the Committee on the Blue-book— Approved his Letters to the Heads of Departments. H.R.U.S. Messages from P.U.S. with Documents of Turkish and Danish Treaties. 2000 copies to be printed laid on the Table Post-Office Inquiry. R. M. Johnson—M’Duffie’s Tariff Bill—his Speech finished. Cambreleng brought me a fresh document of payments by the Bank to Members of Congress for fees— I declined annexing it to my Report, but at his desire withdrew his Instructions and Report upon the Rochester branch. General Macomb and Wetherall here this Evening.

lg.l: Gifts of the Lord our children stand

l.hi: Blest is the man who fears the Lord

lg.l: Rewards for Love and Truth

l.hi: And walks in all his ways

lg.l: As arrows in the Warriors hand,

l.hi: Thy Toils shall meet their sure reward

lg.l: Such, children are my youth
Bless he whose quiver is replete
No shame on him shall fall
He in the gate his foes shall meet
And there destroy them all.
Blest is the man who fears the Lord
And walks in all his ways
Thy Toils shall meet their sure reward
And prosperous prove thy days
Thy wife shall like a fruitful vine
Within thy dwelling spread
Thy Sons like olive plants entwine,
Around thy Table fed

div.p: Committee on Manufactures. Read Letters— I was directed to move in Committee of the whole to lay aside M’Duffie’s Bill and take up ours—

H.R.U.S.—Crawford finished his Speech, attacked my Report. I moved that the Bill should be laid aside— Discussions upon the point of order— Sutherland moves to strike out the first Section of M’Duffie’s Bill— Appleton’s Speech in reply to M’Duffie— Quotations from Malthus, Senior, Ricardo and M’Culloch— Mr Reynolds here this Evening— And J. J. Appleton— Also Jos. M. White. Presidential electioneering.

lg.l: Behold thus blest the man shall be
Who walks in Wisdom’s ways
And thou Jerusalem shalt see
Thus flourish, all thy days
From Zion thy Almighty friend
Thy blessings shall increase,
And to thy Children’s Children send
Prosperity and Peace.
How often, from my youthful day
How bitter foes my life assail’d.
And yet, may grateful Israel say
Against me have they not prevail’d—
Yes, they have harrow’d up my Soul
And plough’d me deep with furrows through
Yet subject to the Lord’s controul
He cuts their galling cords in two

div.p: At the room of the Committee on Manufactures— Returns, from Plymouth, Norfolk, Bristol H.R.U.S—H. Everett and E. Whittlesey’s call on the Post-Office. M’Duffie’s Tariff Bill— Bouldin made half a speech. 4. hours. Spoke to C. J. Ingersoll— Letter to J. W. Murdough— T. L. M’Kenney called this Evening, with three of his friends— on my way to the Capitol I met W. Shaler, now Consul at the Havanna— Also the late Judge Brackenridge of Florida. I attempted to write this Evening, but was obliged to desist and go to bed— The oppression of toil is greater than I can bear.
